item.title: Think I broke JS
item.dc:creator: @Yesteryear Yesteryear
item.description:
@Yesteryear wrote:

Assuming you’re doing the Euler Project. All challenges can be run within one minute. You’re doing something wrong then. Try, for example, using the sieve of eratosthenes to speed up prime number lookup. Also your prime checking function loops through all numbers even though you only need to loop until you’ve found a divisor. After you’ve found one, it’s not necessary to check the rest because you already know that the number is not a prime.
Also you’re starting the loop from 0, but it’s more efficient to start from from the end. That way the first prime factor you find is automatically the largest.

Read full topic

item.title: Think I broke JS
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

Tried solving this problem:

"The prime factors of 13195 are 5, 7, 13 and 29.

What is the largest prime factor of the number 600851475143 ?"

[code]
(function () {

var isPrime = function (x) {
	var count = 0;
	
	for (var i = 0; i < x; i++) {
		if (x % i === 0) {
			count++;
		}
	}

	if (count === 2 || count === 1) {
		return true;
	}

	return false;
};

var numberOfResults = 0;
var listOfPrimeFactors = [];

for (var counter = 0; counter < 600851475143; counter++) {
	if (600851475143 % counter === 0) {
		if (isPrime(counter)) {
			listOfPrimeFactors[numberOfResults] = counter;
                            numberOfResults++;
		}
	}
}

console.log(listOfPrimeFactors[listOfPrimeFactors.length]);

}());[/code]

The program has been running for almost 5 mins… lmao, no result printed

Read full topic
